title: Row intensifies over Telstra's role in NBN fiasco
text:
Nick Minchin, finance minister in the Howard government, also backed Mr Trujillo, saying the American was "terrific for Telstra". "I thought he was making a great contribution to Australia. I'm always disappointed when I see him criticised like that.”

Mr Samuel, who was chairman of the ACCC during the whole of Mr Trujillo's tenure, said: "Sol Trujillo and his team have to take an enormous amount of credit for what happened with the NBN, because it was their approach that said to government. the only way to do this is to build it ourselves." He added he did not use the term "credit" in a positive sense.

"Telstra under Sol Trujillo really made life very, very difficult for government and regulators. They did everything they could to impede competition."

Telstra under Sol Trujillo really made life very, very difficult for government and regulators. — Graeme Samuel, former competition regulator

Mr Samuel said there were two key events that demonstrated this. The first was a proposal made in 2006 to the Howard government to build a fibre-to-the-node broadband network, which the government rejected at the recommendation of the ACCC. The second was Telstra's failure to lodge a compliant bid to build the NBN in 2008 during the Rudd years.

On the 2006 proposal, Mr Samuel said Telstra had wanted to charge retailers a wholesale price that was so high it would have made Telstra's retail competitors uncompetitive.

"Being owners of the network, of course they [Telstra] could beat their competitors on retail price," he said.

"They were saying, unless we get our way on pricing we won’t agree. And the government and the ACCC said, 'No, that’s not on.' The way they wanted to price things was not in the interest of the public or the interest of competition.

Advertisement

"It would still have been a network owned by Telstra, and our clear view was if the network was owned by Telstra you would have a perpetuation of the anti-competitive framework. It didn’t make any sense at all."

He also said Telstra was purposefully obstructing retailers from installing their own equipment in Telstra exchanges. "They tried every trick in the book to prohibit competitors from getting access to the exchange," he said.

Mr McGauchie rejected Mr Samuel's claims.

"We were prepared to give competitors full access, but not at marginal cost, which is what Graeme Samuel wanted. We felt we needed to get a reasonable return on our capital, as any fair review of the facts would show. If shareholders are putting up capital, they need to get a fair return," he said.

He also rejected claims that Telstra blocked competitors from accessing its exchanges. "We would never do that. I completely reject any concept that we were sabotaging anyone."

In 2008, the newly elected Labor government under Kevin Rudd went to tender with a new, more ambitious plan to build a national broadband network.

Telstra was the obvious candidate to build it because it already owned the pits, pipes and ducts needed to roll out the new high-speed fibre optic cable. But Telstra's bid was a non-compliant 12-page document. Labor sought five separate legal opinions before ruling Telstra out of the running. When the other bids, including one from Optus, withdrew or were deemed unsuitable, the government decided to build the NBN itself.

Mr Samuel called Telstra's bid "a nonsense". He said Mr Rudd's response was: "Telstra thinks they're running this country. I'll show them they're wrong."

Advertisement

A Rudd government insider who was involved in the tender process told The Australian Financial Review the government's view at the time was Telstra thought it was calling its bluff, and never expected it to bypass Telstra altogether and build the network itself.

Mr McGauchie also rejected this interpretation. “It’s all very fine to say we didn’t comply. But we couldn't comply because the economics would not have worked.”

He said the purpose of Telstra's bid was "to indicate what was required economically to make the proposal work".

"I’m so cross about this idea we didn’t try and help. We tried to help on both occasions. But what they wanted did not work economically," Mr McGauchie said. Mr Minchin backed up this position.
description: A row has erupted over whether or not Telstra is to blame for sabotaging the construction of the NBN, re-opening a fierce 14-year-old debate.
